response.answer_text: If I answer your question as an originalist; meaning sticking to the question literally, then we can possibly add presidents who were not the elected candidates. First is George W. Bush. The Supreme Court decided that he would be president. We might possibly add John F Kennedy. There were many irregularities in Cook County Illinois and Nixon might have successfully challenged the results if he had chosen to. We can't forget the ignominious election of 1876. A committee was formed to decide who won. I recommend you read what a carnival that election was. In a number of states whoever was in charge of the election commission threw out votes and gave the candidate of  their party the electoral college votes. Tilden won the popular vote by a fair margin. But the fraud that tarnished that election makes it very possible that Rutherfraud B Hayes was not really elected.

Millard Fillmore, Andrew Johnson, Chester A. Arthur, Gerald R. Ford. All others have been elected at least once, including by the Electoral College after losing the popular vote in five cases. Of those, Ford was never elected Vice President either, and is the only President who was never elected President or Vice President. If also counting situations where someone lost the popular vote but still won the electoral college vote, add John Quincy Adams, Rutherford B. Hayes, Benjamin Harrison, and possibly until 2020, Donald Trump (George W. Bush won the popular vote in 2004, so he would not be added in this scenario. If Trump wins the popular vote in 2020, he would fall off this list as well.)

Actually, I would like to throw this in and see what answers come up from some more educated Quora readers than myself… Jefferson Davis was President of the South during the Civil War and while he may not be recognized because it was an -at-the time-unlawful act-he did have many states behind him and for a time the South did actually succeed from the Union thereby the country was broken up for a time. I am wondering if he may be one of the only “unofficial” Presidents we have ever had. Therefor you could say that technically he was not elected.

I read all of the preceding answer. There are some that name presidents that were involved in actual legal elections. Your question is specific. President Gerald R. Ford holds the distinction as the only Vice President or President ever to hold both offices without the benefit of election. One note about Mr. Ford. His highest aspersion was to be Speaker of the House of Representatives. He had no sights on the Oval Office.

Gerald Ford—the only President not elected twice (once when appointed by Nixon, and once when defeated by Carter). Lyndon Johnson—sworn in when Kennedy died Nov. 22, 1963; was re-elected 1964; chose not to run for re-election 1968. Harry S. Truman—sworn in when FDR died April 12, 1945; re-elected 1948. The rest go back before I was born; look ’me up yourself, if interested.

Gerald Ford is the only U.S. president who was never elected to either the presidency or the vice-presidency.  He was appointed by Richard Nixon to fill out the term of Spiro Agnew after the latter's resignation.  When Nixon resigned, Ford became president.

I believe the only president never elected was Gerald Ford. He was appointed as vice president when Spiro Agnew resigned as Nixon's VP. Then when Nixon resigned, Ford became president. He ran for election in 1976 and was defeated by Jimmy Carter.
Gerald Ford, he was not elected to VP nor POTUS. He was the only one to have that distinction.  DM
